conclusion: To determine the power of the external force doing work, we need to consider the forces acting on the conductor rod and the work done by these forces.
The conductor rod is rotating uniformly with an angular velocity ω, the magnetic field B is constant, and the resistance R is connected between O and C.
The magnetic force on the conductor rod is given by F = BIL, where I is the current in the conductor rod.
Since the conductor rod is rotating, the current I changes with time. However, for the purpose of calculating the work done, we can assume a constant current for simplicity.
The work done by the magnetic force is W = ∫(t1 to t2) F · dt = ∫(t1 to t2) BIL · dt.
Since the magnetic field B is constant, the work done by the magnetic force is constant.
The power P of the external force is given by P = W/t, where t is the time.
The work done by the resistance is W = IR · t.
Since the resistance R is constant, the power P is constant.
The power P of the external force is the sum of the work done by the magnetic force and the work done by the resistance.
Therefore, P = W + IR = ∫(t1 to t2) BIL · dt + IR.
The integral of BIL · dt from t1 to t2 is BL · (t2 - t1)/2.
The power of the external force doing work is (1/2)BL · ((t2 - t1)/2) + IR.
